pull.title: optimization: change XOR obfuscation key from `std::vector<std::byte>(8)` to `uint64_t`
pull.body:
The recently merged [XOR obfuscation](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/28207) is a non-trivial part of serialization, encountered during IBD and `reindex`.

In this PR, I've added a new test (comparing randomized inputs against a trivial implementation), updated the benchmark to validate more realistic scenarios (collected every call of `util::Xor` for the first 400k blocks and modelled the benchmark to have the same distribution of data) and optimized the Xor function to do the work in batches (instead of per bytes), migrating the `std::vector<std::byte>(8)` values to `uint64_t` going back until they were read from db.

We could have used `ReadLE64` to unify the byte order for keys and writable values, but that shouldn't be necessary, since both have the same endianness locally that shouldn't be affected by a byte-by-byte xor.

```bash
   cmake -B build -DBUILD_BENCH=ON -DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=Release \
&& cmake --build build -j$(nproc) \
&& build/src/bench/bench_bitcoin -filter='XorSmall|Xor|AutoFileXor' -min-time=10000
```

#### C++ compiler .......................... AppleClang 16.0.0.16000026

> Before:

|             ns/byte |              byte/s |    err% |     total | benchmark
|--------------------:|--------------------:|--------:|----------:|:----------
|                1.49 |      672,907,280.22 |    1.5% |      9.97 | `AutoFileXor`
|               10.54 |       94,860,103.00 |    0.2% |     11.08 | `XorHistogram`

> After:

|             ns/byte |              byte/s |    err% |     total | benchmark
|--------------------:|--------------------:|--------:|----------:|:----------
|                0.53 |    1,881,068,454.54 |    0.5% |      9.74 | `AutoFileXor`
|                4.13 |      242,191,851.33 |    0.3% |     11.05 | `XorHistogram`



#### C++ compiler .......................... GNU 12.2.0

> Before:

|             ns/byte |              byte/s |    err% |        ins/byte |        cyc/byte |    IPC |       bra/byte |   miss% |     total | benchmark
|--------------------:|--------------------:|--------:|----------------:|----------------:|-------:|---------------:|--------:|----------:|:----------
|                1.78 |      563,280,910.13 |    0.2% |            9.20 |            3.58 |  2.571 |           1.03 |    0.1% |     10.68 | `AutoFileXor`
|               22.42 |       44,596,381.28 |    0.4% |           98.44 |           76.26 |  1.291 |          11.49 |    4.6% |     11.13 | `XorHistogram`
> After:

|             ns/byte |              byte/s |    err% |        ins/byte |        cyc/byte |    IPC |       bra/byte |   miss% |     total | benchmark
|--------------------:|--------------------:|--------:|----------------:|----------------:|-------:|---------------:|--------:|----------:|:----------
|                0.85 |    1,170,730,009.58 |    0.1% |            0.71 |            0.46 |  1.531 |           0.16 |    0.2% |     11.02 | `AutoFileXor`
|                9.20 |      108,661,427.63 |    0.1% |           21.05 |           31.29 |  0.673 |           4.80 |   12.3% |     10.97 | `XorHistogram`

i.e. roughly 2-2.5x faster.

<details>
<summary>A few other benchmarks that seem to have improved as well (tested with Clang only)</summary>

> Before:

|               ns/op |                op/s |    err% |     total | benchmark
|--------------------:|--------------------:|--------:|----------:|:----------
|       17,946,959.89 |               55.72 |    0.8% |     10.98 | `AddrManAdd`
|       42,157,347.73 |               23.72 |    0.6% |     11.07 | `AddrManAddThenGood`
|           77,303.31 |           12,936.06 |    0.3% |     10.67 | `AddrManGetAddr`
|        3,288,956.13 |              304.05 |    0.2% |     11.02 | `ReadBlockFromDiskTest`
|        1,095,058.40 |              913.19 |    0.1% |     11.03 | `ReadRawBlockFromDiskTest`

> After:

|               ns/op |                op/s |    err% |     total | benchmark
|--------------------:|--------------------:|--------:|----------:|:----------
|       15,135,779.30 |               66.07 |    0.1% |     11.01 | `AddrManAdd`
|       35,604,977.00 |               28.09 |    0.1% |     10.96 | `AddrManAddThenGood`
|           67,393.96 |           14,838.12 |    0.1% |     10.62 | `AddrManGetAddr`
|        2,678,071.01 |              373.40 |    0.2% |     10.99 | `ReadBlockFromDiskTest`
|           70,052.72 |           14,274.96 |    0.2% |     10.68 | `ReadRawBlockFromDiskTest`

</details>

Also visible on https://corecheck.dev/bitcoin/bitcoin/pulls/31144

----

#### Reproducer and assembly: https://godbolt.org/z/xKvcj8ndW
* _Clang_ (x86-64) - uses SSE (`movdqu`/`pshufd`/`pxor`) for SIMD operations, processing **32** bytes / iteration
* _GCC_ (x86-64) -  uses simple 64-bit operations (`xor` with `QWORD PTR`), processes **16** bytes / iteration
* _RISC-V_ (32-bit) - uses basic 32-bit register operations (`lbu`, `xor`, `srli`, `sb`), processes **8** bytes / iteration

bench: Make Xor benchmark more representative

To make the benchmarks representative, I've collected the write vector's sizes during IBD for every invocation of util::Xor until 400k blocks, and used it as a basis for the micro-benchmarks, having a similar distribution of random data.
Even though we already have serialization tests, `AutoFileXor` was added to serializing 4 MB via the provided key_bytes.

optimization: Xor 64 bits together instead of byte-by-byte

`util::Xor` method was split out into 3 based on usage patterns:
* an aligned `uint64_t` key, doing the first few xors as 64 bits (the memcpy is eliminated in most compilers), and the last iteration, which consumes the key (taking its last byte and shifting it by one byte).
* an unaligned `uint64_t` key with a `key_offset` parameter which is shifted around to accommodate the data.
* a legacy `std::vector<std::byte>` key with an asserted 8 byte size, converted to `uint64_t`.

Asserts were added throughout the code to make sure every such vector has length 8, since in the next commit we're converting all of them to `uint64_t`.

refactor: Migrate fixed-size obfuscation end-to-end from std::vector<std::byte> to uint64_t

Since `util::Xor` accepts `uint64_t` values, we're eliminating any repeated vector-to-uint64_t conversions going back to the loading/saving of these values (we're still serializing them as vectors, but converting as soon as possible to uint64_t).

We're also short-circuit `Xor` calls with 0 key values early to avoid unnecessary calculations (e.g. `MakeWritableByteSpan`).

i have a hard time believing this will make a large difference, especially with the two memcpys involved
On modern CPUs, ALU operations (especially bitwise ones) are so fast compared to any kind of memory access.
And this isn't some advanced crypto math, it's *one* Xor operation per word with a fixed key.

Could avoid the memcpys if the code takes memory alignment into account, but that makes it even more complex. Not sure the pros/cons work out here.

The speedup comes from the vectorized operations, i.e. doing 64 bit xor instead of byte-by-byte xor (memcpy seems to be eliminated on 64 bit architectures successfully), see https://godbolt.org/z/Koscjconz

It's only up to 7 iterations (assuming the key size is 8), sure, youre're right.

But ok, yea, i'm a bit divided about relying on specific non-trivial things being optimized out, makes the output very dependent on specific compiler decisions (which may be fickle in some cases).

Often the simplest code gets optimized most, since it's more predictable.
Would you like me to extend the test or benchmark suite or try something else to make sure we're comfortable with the change?
Right, that's trivial for x86_64. Let's also check for architectures that do require alignment for 64-bit reads and writes, like RISC-V.

I've replaced all vector keys with 64 bit ints, the new peproducer is: https://godbolt.org/z/xKvcj8ndW, which shows:
* _Clang_ (x86-64) - uses SSE (`movdqu`/`pshufd`/`pxor`) for SIMD operations, processing **32** bytes / iteration
* _GCC_ (x86-64) -  uses simple 64-bit operations (`xor` with `QWORD PTR`), processes **16** bytes / iteration
* _RISC-V_ (32-bit) - uses basic 32-bit register operations (`lbu`, `xor`, `srli`, `sb`), processes **8** bytes / iteration

(please validate, my assembly knowledge is only academic)

I've change the usages to avoid std::vector keys, this way GCC and Clang both agree that the new results are faster (even though clang manages to compile to 32 byte SIMD, while GCC only to 16 bytes per iteration, see https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/31144#discussion_r1817939675)
